pages.name: Qualifying Questions

elements.name: Unsafe
elements.title: Is someone making you or your family feel unsafe?
elements.description: Unsafe could be either physical and non-physical behaviour. For example, stalking or verbal harassment could make you or your family feel unsafe.

elements.name: ExplanationFamilyViolence
elements.title:
The term for the things a family member does to make you feel unsafe is called Family Violence.

Family violence includes many things such as:
  • physical abuse (or attempted abuse),
  • denying food or other basic needs,
  • emotional or mental abuse (stalking, threats, intimidation or harassment),
  • sexual abuse (or attempted abuse),
  • children being exposed to family violence
Click here for more information for what counts as Family Violence.

elements.name: UnsafePartner
elements.title: Was (or is) this person your partner?
elements.description: A partner is someone you were (or are) married to, someone you lived (or live) with in a marriage-like relationship, or someone you have a child with.

elements.name: UnsafePartnerFAQ1
elements.title: Is my ex-boyfriend or ex-girlfriend considered a partner?
elements.body: If they lived (or live) with you in a marriage-like relationship for any period of time then, yes, they count as your partner. Also, if the two of you have a child together then, yes, they count as your partner.

elements.name: ExplanationUnsafeNonPartner
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service can only be used to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order against someone who is (or was) your partner.

If a family member that is not your ex-partner is making you feel unsafe, you can still apply for Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order. Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms.

If someone that is not a family member is making you feel unsafe, you can still apply for an order to protect you. This order is called a Peace Bond. This service cannot be used to get a Peace Bond. If you think you need a Peace Bond, contact the police or RCMP for assistance.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: EitherHaveChildren
elements.title: Do either of you have children?

elements.name: ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians
elements.title: Do any of these children have parents or legal guardians other than you and your ex-partner?

elements.name: ExplanationChildrenHaveOtherGuardians
elements.title:
For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service is currently limited to situations where ex-partners have shared children. These children cannot have parents or guardians other than you and your ex-partner.

If any children have parents or guardians other than you and your ex-partner, you can still apply for Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order. Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: UnsafePartnerMultiple
elements.title: Is there more than one ex-partner making you feel unsafe?

elements.name: ExplanationUnsafePartnerMultiple
elements.title: You will still be able to use this service but it currently can only accommodate 1 ex-partner making you feel unsafe at a time. You can use this service more than once for each of the ex-partners making you feel unsafe.

elements.name: OutsideOfBCPOR
elements.title: Does the Protection Order need to be in place outside of British Columbia?
elements.description: A Protection Order lasts for one year unless the judge orders a different end date.

elements.name: ExplanationOutsideOfBCPOR
elements.visibleIf: {Unsafe} =  'y' and {UnsafePartner} = 'y' and ({EitherHaveChildren} = 'n' or {ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians} = 'n') and {UnsafePartnerMultiple} notempty and {OutsideOfBCPOR} = 'y'
elements.title:
Depending on the place, a Provincial Court Familiy Law Protection Order may not be valid outside of British Columbia.

You may consider a Peace Bond or a Supreme Court Family Law Protection Order. This onine service cannot help apply for either of these at this time. You may consider legal advice for looking into the place where the family member making you feel unsafe is located.

Click here to learn more about Peace Bonds.

Click here for Supreme Court Family Forms.

elements.name: ExistingPOR
elements.visibleIf: {Unsafe} =  'y' and {UnsafePartner} = 'y' and ({EitherHaveChildren} = 'n' or {ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians} = 'n') and {UnsafePartnerMultiple} notempty and {OutsideOfBCPOR} = 'n'
elements.title: Do you already have a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order and you need to change it or add more time?

elements.name: ExplanationExistingPOR
elements.visibleIf: {Unsafe} =  'y' and {UnsafePartner} = 'y' and ({EitherHaveChildren} = 'n' or {ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians} = 'n') and {UnsafePartnerMultiple} notempty and {OutsideOfBCPOR} = 'n' and {ExistingPOR} = 'y'
elements.title:
If you already have a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order, there is a different form to complete.

Click here to go to the Provincial Court Family Forms page.

Look for the form named "Application respecting existing orders or agreements" (PCFR Form 2).

You can copy most of the content from the original forms you used to apply for your Protection Order.

elements.name: PORConfirmed
elements.visibleIf: {Unsafe} =  'y' and {UnsafePartner} = 'y' and ({EitherHaveChildren} = 'n' or {ChildrenHaveOtherGuardians} = 'n') and {UnsafePartnerMultiple} notempty and {OutsideOfBCPOR} = 'n' and {ExistingPOR} = 'n'
elements.title:
You appear to meet the requirements to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order.

You may also want to consider applying for a Peace Bond, which is another kind of Protection Order. A Peace Bond can do everything a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order can do. A Peace Bond can also protect your property.

To apply for a Family Law Protection Order, you will need to tell your story in person to a judge in Family Court. You can apply on your own or you can hire a lawyer to help. A judge may decide to make your Protection Order without your ex-partner needing to be in court.

To get a Peace Bond, you will need to tell your story to the police or the RCMP. The police may decide to tell your story to Crown Counsel. Crown Counsel will then decide if a judge is likely to make your Protection Order. Your ex-partner will have an opportunity to tell their story. You may be called as witness.

You can also apply for both Protection Orders at the same time.

Click here for more information about the differences between a Peace Bond and a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order.

Confirm that you want to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order.

choices.text: I want to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order

pages.title: Before we begin...
pages.description: There is more than one kind of order that can protect you and your family. This service is for applying for a protection order under the Family Law Act. The following questions will help you decide if the Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order is right for you.
